Oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane (ODHE) is a promising ethylene production process with low energy consumption and potential industrial applications; however, the development of metal-based catalysts with high selectivity of ethylene remains a formidable challenge. TiO2 is extensively employed as a catalyst support, but further investigation is still required for its application as a catalyst for the oxidative dehydrogenation of light alkanes. Herein, the Si-doped TiO2 catalyst (xSi-TiO2) prepared by the co-assembly method has been found to improve the ODHE performance of pure TiO2. The results demonstrated the formation of Si-O-Ti bonds upon incorporating Si atoms into the TiO2 lattice, leading to an increased surface area of TiO2 and effectively regulating the acidity of TiO2 as well as the oxygen defects/holes on its surface. Consequently, this facilitates enhanced ethane conversion and inhibits deep oxidation reactions. At 600 °C, the 0.05Si-TiO2 catalyst with 5 % Si content showed an ethane conversion of 18.8 % and an ethylene selectivity of 64.3 %. Graphical abstract Compared pure TiO2, the selectivity towards ethylene and ethane conversion over Si-doped TiO2 with oxygen defects are improved. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane Si incorporation TiO2 Oxygen defects Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Given the escalating proven recoverable reserves of natural gas/shale gas resources and the continuous refinement of extraction technology, the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane to ethylene (ODHE) is recognized as a pivotal approach to advancing light-carbon production of ethylene, thus holding significant scientific and strategic significance [1,2]. The process is not constrained by thermodynamic equilibrium, effectively mitigates the carbon deactivation of the catalyst, and exhibits low energy consumption, thereby garnering widespread attention in academic circles. However, ethane and ethylene undergo further conversion into complete oxidation products (CO and CO2) under oxidizing conditions, leading to a decrease in selectivity towards ethylene [3,4]. Therefore, the design and preparation of a highly efficient catalyst are crucial for enhancing the energy efficiency of ethylene production. Among various catalyst systems [5–12], traditional metal oxides exhibit superior catalytic performance; however, they tend to induce excessive oxidation of olefins. Among them, MoVTeNbOx mixed oxide [6,13–17] and Ni-M composites [10,18–21] are considered promising ODHE catalysts due to their exceptional catalytic performance at low temperatures. During the reaction, the ODHE reaction over both catalysts followed the Mars-Krevelen mechanism, wherein lattice oxygen species played an important role [11]. Therefore, the catalytic performance of reducible oxide catalysts can be optimized by modulating the surface oxygen species. Recently, Tao et al. demonstrated that incorporating Si atoms in the Co3O4 lattice can substantially enhance ethylene selectivity by suppressing the deep oxidation of reactive molecules [22]. The experimental results showed that the selectivity towards ethylene over Si0.2-Co3O4 catalyst was approximately 40 % higher than that over pure Co3O4 at 600 °C. Compared with traditional reducible metal oxides, the inexpensive and weakly reducible TiO2 is frequently utilized as a promoter or support to improve catalyst performance. For instance, the introduction of TiO2 has been demonstrated by Chen et al. to significantly increase the reduction/re-oxidation rate of lattice oxygen species in M1 MoVTeNbOx/TiO2 catalyst, thus effectively augmenting its ODHE performance. Sanchis et al. employed TiO2 with a high specific surface area as a support to significantly improve the selectivity of ethylene over bulk NiO. The catalyst exhibited optimal ODHE performance when the NiO load was in the range of 5–10 theoretical monolayers [23]. However, Wang et al. were the only researchers to investigate TiO2 as a catalyst for the ODHE reaction [11]. The findings show the presence of Ti and oxygen vacancy defects on M-TiO2 derived from Ti3C2Tx MXene, which play a key role in the activation of the ethane CH bond. The ethylene productivity over this catalyst reached 15.4 g C 2 H 4 · g cat − 1 · h − 1 , exhibiting a fourfold increase compared with that of P25. After considering the aforementioned research, non-metallic silicon was selected as the promoter due to its strong bonding ability with oxygen atoms. The chemical state of oxygen species on the surface of pure TiO2 material was modulated by incorporating Si atoms, aiming to optimize its ODHE performance. The experimental results showed that Si-TiO2 exhibited higher C2H6 conversion and C2H4 selectivity compared with pure TiO2 under identical test conditions. The characterization results confirmed that Si incorporation not only exerted a significant influence on the texture and acidity of TiO2, but also induced abundant oxygen defects on its surface. In this study, the ODHE performance of TiO2 was enhanced through a facile doping method, thus offering a novel approach for its improvement. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) and ethyl alcohol (CH3CH2OH) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Tetraisopropyl titanate (TIPT) and 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. The chemicals employed in this study are commercially available reagents and were utilized without additional purification. 2.2 Preparation of Si-incorporated TiO2 catalysts 2.5 g of CTAB was dissolved in a solution containing 64 mL of deionized water and 16 mL of CH3CH2OH, followed by stirring at 30 °C until complete dissolution. Subsequently, TTIP (10 g) was added and continuously stirred for 1 h Then, the calculated amount of APTES was gradually added to the aforementioned solution and vigorously stirred for 24 h After completion of stirring, the resulting mixture was filtered, followed by three washings with CH3CH2OH and drying at 60 °C for 12 h Finally, the dried samples were calcined at 450 °C with a heating rate of 2 °C/min for 5 h The obtained Si-incorporated TiO2 catalysts are designated as xSi-TiO2, where x represents the nominal molar ratio of Si to Ti, ranging from 0 to 0.1. Furthermore, the Si-TiO2 catalysts were prepared by calcination in air at various temperatures for 5 h and designated as Si-TiO2-T. 2.3 Characterization The structure of Si-TiO2 catalysts was characterized using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD) equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm, RIGAKU Ultima IV X) over a 2θ range of 10–90°. The identification of the catalyst phase was confirmed by comparing it with the JCPDS standard XRD database. The N2 adsorption-desorption experiments were conducted using the Micromeritics TriStar Ⅱ 3020 physical adsorption instrument at −196 °C. The BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) and BJH (Barrett- Joyner-Halenda) methods were employed to determine the specific surface area and pore size distribution of the sample. The Raman spectra were acquired using a Horiba LabRAM HR Evolution Raman spectrometer at room temperature, excited with a 266 nm laser. Prior to the measurements, the system was calibrated using a Silicon wafer. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) test was conducted using the Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi instrument equipped with an Al Kα excitation source (15 mA and 15 kV). The binding energies were calibrated by referencing the C 1 s peak of contaminant carbon (BE = 284.6 eV). The detailed morphology and internal structure of the Si-TiO2 catalysts were examined by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi SU8010) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, THERMO FEI TALOS F200X), respectively. The NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) experiments were conducted using the Micromeritics Auto Chem 2920 multi-functional dynamic adsorption instrument. The detailed operational procedure is as follows: 0.1 g of sample was introduced into the quartz tube for characterization. Prior to analysis, the sample was pretreated by flowing He at 300 °C for 1 h, followed by cooling to ambient temperature. Subsequently, pure ammonia was introduced and allowed to adsorb for a period of 30 min. Helium was then used as a purging agent to eliminate physically adsorbed NH3 from the catalyst surface. The target temperature was reached by ramping the temperature at a programmed rate of 10 °C/min under a continuous helium flow, while mass spectrometry was used to monitor the desorbed species. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was performed at 77 K using a Bruker EPR A200 spectrometer with a 100 kHz magnetic field modulation. 2.4 Catalytic performance testing Catalytic tests were conducted in a fixed bed reactor equipped with a quartz tube (φ = 6 mm, id = 40 mm) in the temperature range of 500–600 °C. 0.3 g Si-TiO2 catalyst mixed with 1 g quartz sand was immobilized in the quartz tube using quartz cotton, and the reaction temperature was regulated using a coaxial thermocouple. The gas flow rate was regulated using MFC electronic flow meters, while maintaining a volume ratio of C2H6, O2 and N2 at 1:1:8 (F total = 30 mL/min). Additionally, real-time qualitative and quantitative analysis of the products was conducted using an N gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890B) equipped with two detectors (FID and TCD) and four columns. The separation and quantification of hydrocarbons, including CH4, C2H4 and C2H6, were achieved using HP-Plot Q and HP-FFAP columns. For the separation and quantification of O2, N2, CO and CO2, Porapak Q and 5A molecular sieve columns were employed. The C2H6 conversion, products selectivity, and C2H4 yield in the experiment can be determined by the following equations: A i = f r × C n × A i ′ S i ( % ) = A i / ∑ A i × 100 % X C 2 H 6 ( % ) = ∑ Ai / ( ∑ Ai + A C 2 H 6 , out ) × 100 % Y C 2 H 4 ( % ) = S C 2 H 4 × X C 2 H 6 × 100 % Where Ai: relative quantity of product i; Ai’: the peak area of product i detected by online gas chromatography; f r: relative correction factor based on ethane; Cn: the number of carbon atoms contained in a reactant or product. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance The variation of C2H6 conversion and C2H4 selectivity over TiO2 and xSi-TiO2 catalysts with reaction temperature is depicted in Fig. 1 . The ethane conversions over TiO2 remained consistently below 10 % across the entire range of reaction temperatures, in accordance with previous literature findings that highlight the limited reactivity of TiO2 in ODHE [11]. However, the activation ability of TiO2 towards ethane was observed to be improved to some extent after the incorporation of Si into TiO2 (Fig. 1A). The 0.10Si-TiO2 catalyst achieved a remarkable ethane conversion of 22.1 % at 600 °C, which is twice as high as that of TiO2. Additionally, the selectivity towards ethylene over Si-TiO2 catalysts can be significantly improved (Fig. 1B). For example, the C2H4 selectivity over the TiO2 sample is merely 39.2 % at 600 °C, with CO being the predominant product. The ethylene selectivity of the 0.05Si-TiO2 catalyst exceeds 60 % within the temperature range of 500–600 °C. In terms of C2H4 selectivity, the order among various catalysts is as follows: 0.05Si-TiO2 > 0.10Si-TiO2 > 0.01Si-TiO2 > TiO2. Although 0.05Si-TiO2 exhibits high selectivity towards ethylene, its ethane conversion is lower compared with that of the 0.10Si-TiO2 catalyst. Consequently, the ethylene yield obtained over 0.05Si-TiO2 is lower than that over 0.10Si-TiO2 under identical reaction temperatures (Fig. 1C). To investigate the impact of calcination temperature on the ODHE performance of Si-TiO2 catalysts, we further compared the catalytic activities of 0.05Si-TiO2 catalysts prepared at calcination temperatures of 450 °C, 550 °C, 600 °C, and 650 °C. As shown in Fig. S1A, the ethane conversion initially increases and subsequently decreases as the calcination temperature rises. Specifically, the ethane conversions over the 0.05Si-TiO2-T catalysts are ranked as follows: 0.05Si-TiO2–550 °C > 0.05Si-TiO2–450 °C > 0.05Si-TiO2–600 °C > 0.05Si-TiO2–650 °C. However, as illustrated in Fig. S1B, the selectivity to ethylene exhibits an inverse trend, decreasing with increasing calcination temperature. Among all the evaluated samples, the 0.05Si-TiO2–450 °C catalyst shows the highest C2H4 selectivity. The influence of contact time (W/F, where W represents the dosage of the catalyst and F is the total flow rate of reaction gas) on the ODHE performance of the 0.05Si-TiO2 catalyst is shown in Fig. 2 . A decrease in W/F is observed to result in an increase in C2H4 selectivity from 60.2 % to 76.0 %, accompanied by a reduction in CO selectivity (from 36.9 % → 23.3 %) and C2H6 conversion (from 14.6 % → 6.6 %), while no significant change is observed in CO2 selectivity (from 2.7 % to 0.6 %). This is comprehensible. Nonetheless, shorter contact times inevitably diminish the interaction between ethane, oxygen, and the catalyst, thereby weakening the deep oxidation of ethylene. The oxidizability of Si-TiO2 alone fails to sufficiently facilitate the direct oxidation of ethylene to CO2, resulting in a low content of CO2 in the products. 3.2 Catalyst characterization The XRD patterns of xSi-TiO2 catalysts with varying Si contents are presented in Fig. 3 . The pure TiO2 sample exhibits characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ angles of 25.3°, 37.7°, 48.0°, 53.8°, 54.9°, 62.6° and 68.6°, which are consistent with the (101), (111), (200), (105), (211), (204) and (116) crystal planes of anatase TiO2 (JCPDS Card No 21–1272) [24]. The XRD patterns do not show any characteristic peaks corresponding to the rutile phase of TiO2 or SiO2. Additionally, the intensity of the diffraction peak presents an initial rise followed by a subsequent decline with increasing Si content. The incorporation of a small quantity of Si is advantageous for improving the crystallinity of TiO2; however, the formation of numerous Si-O-Ti bonds can compromise its crystalline structure. Furthermore, the diffraction peak of TiO2 broadens with an increase in Si content, implying that Si doping facilitates a reduction in the particle size of TiO2. The specific surface area and pore structure of xSi-TiO2 catalysts were determined by N2 adsorption-desorption measurements, as illustrated in Fig. 4 . All the catalysts show type IV isotherms and demonstrate distinct N2 adsorption behavior in three regions: in the low-pressure region (P/P 0 < 0.4), a significant enhancement in N2 saturation adsorption is observed, primarily attributed to the monolayer adsorption; in the medium-pressure region (0.4 < P/P 0 < 0.9), N2 adsorption occurs via capillary condensation within mesoporous channels [25]; in the high-pressure region (0.9 < P/P 0 < 1.0), complete pore filling by liquefied N2 indicates the presence of macroporous structures in the samples. The specific surface area and pore size of TiO2 and xSi-TiO2 catalysts are presented in Table 1 . The specific surface area of TiO2 determined by the BET model is merely 49 m2/g, while it simultaneously exhibits an average pore size of 8.2 nm. The introduction of Si into TiO2 leads to a significant increase in the specific surface area, with the 0.05Si-TiO2 catalyst exhibiting the highest value of 119 m2/g. The increase in specific surface area is attributed to the formation of Ti-O-Si bonds on the surface of TiO2 during the TTIP and APTES hydrolysis, thereby inhibiting the formation of anatase TiO2 and the growth of crystalline grains. With the further increase of Si content to 10 %, the specific surface area of the Si-TiO2 catalyst decreases, potentially attributed to the partial pore blockage caused by excessive SiO2. The specific surface area of xSi-TiO2 catalysts follows the order: 0.05Si-TiO2 (119 m2/g) > 0.10Si-TiO2 (97 m2/g) > 0.01Si-TiO2 (81 m2/g) > TiO2 (49 m2/g). The textural properties of the 0.05Si-TiO2 catalysts were further compared before and after the reaction, as well as after calcination at 600 °C. The results revealed a decrease in surface area and an increase in average pore size following the reaction and calcination at 600 °C (Table 1), potentially attributed to sintering. The morphology of xSi-TiO2 catalyst was examined using a scanning electron microscope (SEM). As shown in Fig. 5 , all the samples comprise irregularly shaped nanoparticles with varying sizes. However, an increase in Si content leads to a gradual enlargement of the nanoparticle sizes. Notably, at a Si doping level of 10 %, larger particles are observed, indicating that Si doping significantly alters the structural characteristics of TiO2. TEM images of TiO2 and 0.05Si-TiO2 samples are presented in Fig. 6 . The examination of Fig. 6A and C reveals that both TiO2 and 0.05Si-TiO2 samples exhibit a stacked arrangement of diverse nanoparticles, with the presence of abundant worm-like irregular pores interspersed among these nanoparticles. By comparing the two samples, it can be observed that the nanoparticles in the 0.05Si-TiO2 sample are comparatively smaller in size. As depicted in Fig. 6B, the lattice fringe spacing of pure TiO2 is determined to be 0.35 nm, corresponding to the (101) crystal face of anatase TiO2 [26]. Likewise, 0.05Si-TiO2 shows distinct lattice fringes with a spacing of 0.35 nm (Fig. 6D), which is identical to that observed in pure TiO2. Additionally, the absence of SiO2 particles in amorphous form indicates that Si ions may be incorporated into the TiO2 lattice rather than existing as surface oxides, which aligns with the XRD characterization results. The EDX mapping reveals a uniform distribution of Si, O, and Ti elements throughout the 0.05Si-TiO2 sample (Fig. 6E-H). The XPS analysis was conducted to further investigate the surface composition and bonding environment of pure TiO2 and 0.05Si-TiO2 catalysts. In the high-resolution XPS spectra of pure TiO2, two symmetric spectral peaks are detected at the binding energies of 458.6 eV and 464.4 eV (Fig. 7 A), corresponding to the Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2 orbitals, respectively. The measured difference in binding energy between the two peaks, ΔE b = 5.8 eV, indicates a prevalence of Ti4+ species in the examined sample. In contrast, the XPS peaks of Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2 in the 0.05Si-TiO2 sample shift to 458.8 eV and 464.5 eV [27], respectively. The broad peak of O 1 s for pure TiO2 in Fig. 7B can be deconvoluted into two distinct peaks with binding energies of 529.8 eV and 531.2 eV, indicating the presence of two distinct chemical states of oxygen species within the analyzed sample [28]. The former is generated by the lattice oxygen of TiO2, whereas the latter corresponds to the oxygen vacancy defects (Ov) [29,30]. Similarly, Si doping induces a shift towards higher binding energy in the broad peaks of the O 1 s spectrum. These results demonstrate the successful incorporation of Si into the TiO2 lattice, leading to the formation of Ti-O-Si bonds by replacing some Ti atoms. Moreover, XPS quantitative analysis reveals an increase in surface oxygen vacancy in the 0.05Si-TiO2 sample compared with pure TiO2, indicating that Si doping promotes surface Ov of TiO2. In the XPS spectrum of Si 2p for the 0.05Si-TiO2 sample, the Si 2p XPS spectrum can be deconvoluted into two distinct peaks located at 101.9 and 103.0 eV (Fig. 7C), corresponding to the Ti-O-Si and Si-O-Si bonds [22,31], respectively. This confirms that Si has been successfully incorporated into the lattice of TiO2. Meanwhile, the observed binding energy of the Si-O-Si bond (101.9 eV) is lower than that of pure SiO2 (103.4 eV) [32], providing further evidence that Si doping results in the formation of Si-O-Ti bonds rather than isolated SiO2 layers. In order to acquire more structural information about the Si-TiO2 sample, Raman spectroscopy was employed to characterize both pure TiO2 and 0.05Si-TiO2 catalysts. As depicted in Fig. 8 A, the Raman spectrum of pure TiO2 presents characteristic modes of anatase TiO2, including E g, E g, B 1 g, B 1 g and E g at wavenumbers of 144, 197, 398, 518 and 638 cm-1 [33,34], respectively. The enlarged view in Fig. 8A reveals a decrease in the intensity of Raman peak for 0.05Si-TiO2 compared with that of pure TiO2, indicating that the incorporation of Si exerts a discernible influence on the structure of TiO2. However, the position of the Raman peak exhibits a slight shift towards higher wavenumbers, possibly due to the presence of oxygen vacancies [35]. EPR characterization further confirms the presence of oxygen vacancies on the surface of these samples (Fig. 8B). The EPR signal of the 0.05Si-TiO2 sample is found to be stronger than that of pure TiO2 at g = 2.003, suggesting that Si doping promotes the formation of oxygen vacancies in TiO2 [30,36]. The observed increase in EPR peak intensity could potentially arise from either substitution of Ti4+ ions with Si4+ ions or the distortion of the surrounding environment of Ti4+ ions induced by Si within the gap. The promotion of oxygen vacancies facilitates the adsorption and activation of gas molecules, thereby improving the catalytic performance, which aligns with the catalytic performance evaluation results. The acidity of catalysts has been reported to impact their catalytic performance [37]. Therefore, the NH3-TPD technique was employed to characterize the xSi-TiO2 catalysts. As illustrated in Fig. 9 , pure TiO2 shows a broad peak in the range of 100–500 °C, which can be attributed to weak and medium-strong acid sites. Additionally, a distinct NH3 desorption peak corresponding to strong acid sites is observed at approximately 651 °C [38]. Compared with pure TiO2, the intensity of the desorption peaks for weak and medium-strong acid sites in 0.01Si-TiO2 and 0.05Si-TiO2 samples shows a slight increase. Notably, the enhancement of medium-strong acid sites is more pronounced in the 0.05Si-TiO2 sample. When the Si/Ti molar ratio is further increased to 0.10, the strength of the weak and medium-strong acid sites decreases, while the intensity of strong acid sites increases. 4 Conclusions In summary, silicon-doped TiO2 catalysts were successfully synthesized via a one-pot method and employed as catalysts for the ODHE reaction. Compared with pure TiO2, Si-TiO2 catalysts showed higher ethane conversions and selectivities towards ethylene. At 600 °C, the ethane conversion of the 0.10Si-TiO2 catalyst was observed to be 22 %, with a corresponding ethylene yield of 13.1 %. The characterization results revealed that the incorporation of non-metallic Si into the TiO2 lattice facilitated the formation of Si-O-Ti bonds, inducing the detachment of certain oxygen atoms from the TiO2 lattice and generating oxygen defects, thereby promoting the activation of ethane. Moreover, Si incorporation can also increase the specific surface area of TiO2, thus facilitating increased contact opportunities between the active sites and the reactants. Additionally, this reduction in acidity also contributes to an improvement in olefin selectivity. This work demonstrates that the enhancement of catalytic performance in metal oxides with limited reducibility can be achieved by regulating of surface reactive oxygen species through nonmetallic doping. coredata.dc:description: Oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane (ODHE) is a promising ethylene production process with low energy consumption and potential industrial applications; however, the development of metal-based catalysts with high selectivity of ethylene remains a formidable challenge. TiO2 is extensively employed as a catalyst support, but further investigation is still required for its application as a catalyst for the oxidative dehydrogenation of light alkanes. Herein, the Si-doped TiO2 catalyst (xSi-TiO2) prepared by the co-assembly method has been found to improve the ODHE performance of pure TiO2. The results demonstrated the formation of Si-O-Ti bonds upon incorporating Si atoms into the TiO2 lattice, leading to an increased surface area of TiO2 and effectively regulating the acidity of TiO2 as well as the oxygen defects/holes on its surface. Consequently, this facilitates enhanced ethane conversion and inhibits deep oxidation reactions. At 600 °C, the 0.05Si-TiO2 catalyst with 5 % Si content showed an ethane conversion of 18.8 % and an ethylene selectivity of 64.3 %.
